metadata.title: Enhancing the sensitivity of graphene/polyurethane nanocomposite flexible piezo-resistive pressure sensors with magnetite nano-spacers

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Carbon
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /carbon
Enhancing the sensitivity of graphene/polyurethane nanocomposite flexible piezo-resistive pressure sensors with magnetite nano-spacers
T.T. Tung a, C. Robert a, M. Castro a, J.F. Feller a, *, T.Y. Kim b, K.S. Suh c
a Smart Plastics Group, Bretagne Loire University (UBL), IRDL CNRS 3744 -UBS, Lorient, France b Department of Materials Science & Engineering, Korea University, Seoul, South Korea c Electronic Materials & Device Research Centre, Korea Electronics Technology Institute, Gyeonggi-do, South Korea
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 23 April 2016 Received in revised form 24 June 2016 Accepted 9 July 2016 Available online 25 July 2016
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: jean-francois.feller@univ-ubs.fr (J.
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2016.07.018 0008-6223/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
A robust piezo-resistive nanocomposite flexible sensor has been developed using an innovative combination of materials, i.e., magnetite-decorated graphene/poly(ionic liquid) compatibilized poly(urethane) (TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL). The transducer has been fabricated by spray layer by layer (sLbL) to structure an original three-dimensional architecture in which: reduced graphene oxide (RGO) platelets are used to build the conducting network, PIL stabilizes this percolated assembly, Fe3O4 NP act as nanospacers between platelets to prevent their stacking and facilitate their switching, and TPU matrix brings cohesion and flexibility to the whole assembly. This strategy results in highly sensitive TPU/Fe3O4@RGOPIL flexible nanocomposite sensors (high gauge factor in pure compression up to 6.2, exceptionally low threshold pressure 0.5 kPa, Negative Pressure Coefficient), yielding a linear response in a large range of pressures (10e200 kPa), with robust and reproducible piezo-resistive properties (weak hysteresis upon loading unloading cycling, stability of signals up to 100 000 cycles, with 2 ms dephasing). These performances are promising for a variety of applications in flexible and wearable electronics, such as tactile sensors, sensing skins and compressive strain sensors.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Piezo-resistive materials able to convert stress into an interpretable signal are finding applications in variety of areas such as automotive, aerospace, manufacturing plants, heavy machinery, and sport-wear products [1e3]. Doped silicone is a well-known piezo-resistive material for pressure sensors, because of its high piezo-resistive strain coefficient (gauge factor) [4]. However, silicon-based sensors have an issue on their reliability, because their sensing response is highly dependent on the environmental parameter such as temperature and moisture. The integration of silicon onto mechanically flexible substrates or flexible MEMS devices is also limited due to its high processing temperatures [5e7]. Thus alternative piezo-resistive materials such as fibres (carbon, glass, aramid, etc.) reinforced polymer composites (FRPC) are being increasingly used in the industry [8e11]. At present, carbon nanotubes (CNT) are particularly interesting for the next generation of piezo-resistive materials because of their possible local bonding
F. Feller).
change from sp2 to sp3 and the band gap opening [12,13]. In particular conditions, CNT can lead to gauge factor as high as 100 or even 200, which surpasses those of doped Si and metals. However, CNT are still difficult develop in large-area devices because of variations in chirality [14], difficulty of dispersion and high cost of production, which limits their widespread use [15]. Recently, twodimensional (2D) materials including graphene (a monolayer of graphite) and transition-metal dichalcogenides (MoS2, MoSe2, WS2) have attracted a great interest owing to their unique electronic, mechanical, thermal and piezo-electrical properties [16e23]. It has been reported that the high specific surface area along with two-dimensional geometry of graphene is superior to one-dimensional nanotubes, which is a key enabler in enhancing the mechanical properties of polymer composites as compared to CNT [24e29]. Among various forms of graphene-based materials, chemically modified graphene has beenwidely explored for various applications including sensing devices because they possess chemically active sites and are available in a wide range of processable forms [30e35]. In order to further explore its potential, the researchers are experimenting ways to functionalize graphenewith nanoparticles (NP). Hybrid materials consisting of graphene and NP
could potentially display not only the unique properties of NP and those of graphene, but also additional novel properties due to the synergistic interaction between them [36,37]. In this respect, hybrids of chemically modified graphene with magnetic nanoparticles (i. e., Fe3O4 NP) are also a good option to produce a new type of sensing materials with tailored structures and functions [38e44].
In this work, we have investigated the potentiality of graphene nanofoils to build an original conducting architecture with enhanced piezo-resistive properties for the design of tactile sensing skins. The idea was to use a poly(urethane) matrix to host and protect the percolated conducting network, and use poly(ionic liquid) to effectively disperse and stabilize carbon platelets preventing graphene aggregation, whereas 5e15 nm diameters Fe3O4 nanoparticles would act as nano-spacers increasing compression potential [45]. This strategy was expected to provide a thin film of hybrid nanomaterial combining robustness and high sensitivity to pressure.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nanocomposite sensors' preparation
sections.text:
Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared by a modified Hummer's method from graphite flake [46,47], PIL of poly(1-vinyl-3ethylimidazolium) salts bearing the anion (Br ) was synthesized according to the literature [48e50]. And Fe3O4 nanoparticledecorated reduced graphene oxide mediated by PIL (Fe3O4@RGOPIL) was prepared as described in our previous work [45].
To synthesize a nanocomposite from the dispersion of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanofillers in a TPU matrix, the as-prepared Fe3O4@RGO-PIL was transferred from aqueous into organic phase using PIL as phase transferring medium. For this process, an aqueous suspension of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL was mixed with a saturate aqueous solution of lithium bis(trifluoro methyl sulfonyl)amide (LiþNTf2 ) for the anion exchange of PIL. The addition of LiþNTf2 leads to an immediate replacement of hydrophilic and water soluble Br anions in the PIL with hydrophobic and water-immiscible NTf2
anions. As-produced Fe3O4@RGO-PIL became readily dispersible in a range of low boiling-point organic solvent such as acetone, acetonitrile, methyl ethyl ketone (MEK). A TPU/ Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposite was prepared with the concentrations of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL varied from 0.5 to 10% by weigh (i. e., 0.5, 1, 3, 5, 8, 10 wt%). In the typical procedure, 250 mg of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL were dispersed in 100 cm3of MEK with the aid of 15 min ultrasonication, followed by stirring with a magnetic bar for 2 h.
Thermoplastic poly(urethane) TPU (Irostic S9815, Huntsman, Germany) pellets (2.5 g) were added to 100 cm3 MEK and stirred at 30 C for 1 day. This polymer solution was then mixed with the above Fe3O4@RGO-PIL suspensions and stirred at room temperature for additional 5 h to yield the homogeneous dispersion of Fe3O4@RGO in TPU solution. Subsequently, the mixed solution was cast on poly(propylene) plates and kept in the oven at 70 C under vacuum for 3 h to evaporate the solvent. The dried mixture was fully milled at 80 C using a three rolls mill calender. The difference in velocities between the different rolls and the gap between the rolls induces a high shear stress promoting a good dispersion. This gap was set up to 6 mm and six successive mixing were performed in order to disperse and homogenize the composite. Finally, the roll-milled composite was compounded with a hot press at 100 C under 10 000 kg of load for 30 min and then cooled down to room temperature to obtain the laminated sample. The thickness of sample can be controlled by choosing an appropriate mould.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization's techniques
sections.text:
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded using a JEOL JSM-700F microscope operated at 15.0 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a TECNAI 20 operating at 200 kV. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) measurements were performed in tapping mode with an AFM XE100. Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements were performed at a heating rate of 10 C min 1 under nitrogen flow using a NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG instrument. Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) was performed using a DMA 50N analyser from TA Instruments (USA). A three-point bending clamping geometry was used. DMA test was carried out from 100 to 80 C at a heating rate of 5 C min 1 at 1 Hz. The surface resistance was obtained using a four-probe method (CMT-SR2000N) at room temperature.
The piezo-resistive properties were measured using a uniaxial dynamic pressure test system consisting in a universal testing machine (Instr€on 5566A) and electrometers (Fluke 8842A and 8846A) controlled by a Labview™ program. To test the piezoresistive behaviour of TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposite films of thickness 0.1 mm, they were cut in the form of 25 mm diameter disks and clamped between two copper plates of same diameter that were used as electrodes. The later were connected to a multimeter to measure the nanocomposite films' resistance. A compressive stress was then applied to the sample in the direction of resistance's measurement. The experimental setup used to investigate the piezo-resistive properties is described in Fig. 1. The pressure applied on the specimen was provided by a compression machine and increased on the electrodes, yielding responses under the form of relative difference of resistance. Three specimens of each type were tested in order to ensure statistical significance to the data. All experiments were done in controlled atmosphere, i.e., T¼ 23 C, RH ¼ 51%. The relative difference of resistance amplitude or piezo-resistive response (AR) of sensors was recorded with a PICOTEST multimeter and defined by Eq. (1):
Ar ¼ DRR0 ¼ R R0 R0 (1)
where R is the resistance under an applied pressure and Ro is the quiescent resistance.

sections.heading: 3.1. Morphology of nanocomposite sensors
sections.text:
The microstructures of both Fe3O4@RGO-PIL complex and TPU/ Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites were investigated by SEM and TEM. The SEM images of drop-cast samples are clearly showing in Fig. 2a a wrinkled surface texture characteristic of the full exfoliation of Fe3O4 NP e decorated graphene platelets and in Fig. 2b their perfect embedment into the TPU matrix expected to favour the mechanical interlocking with the polymer phase [26]. The TEM image of Fig. 2c shows the discrete presence of Fe3O4 spherical nanoparticles (dark spots) with diameters in the range of 5e15 nm decorating the graphene sheets surface. Fig. 2d is also confirming the homogeneity of Fe3O4@RGO randomly distributed in TPU matrix without any specific orientation.
Herein, the PIL serves as both stabilizer of graphene platelets in the suspension and phase transfer agent fromwater to low boiling point organic solvent MEK, which avoids the aggregation of conductive fillers during the relatively rapid solvent evaporation. Fe3O4 NP are also expected to decrease the density of the Fe3O4@RGO network, hence preventing a restacking of graphene sheets. The microstructure of TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites
was further analysed by AFM. The specimens for AFM imaging were prepared by spin-coating a TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL suspension onto a silicon wafer substrate. The AFM image of Fig. S2 (in supporting information) suggests a 3D-laminated structure of TPU/ Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites.

sections.heading: 3.2. Thermo-physical properties
sections.text:
Fig. 3a shows the flexible character of a 0.1mm thick film of TPU/ Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposite prepared by hot pressing. The specimen carries both electrical and magnetic properties that can be finely tuned by controlling the Fe3O4@RGO content in the TPU matrix. The determination of nanocomposite's percolation as a function of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL content is shown in Fig. 3b. The
conductivity (s) of the films was calculated from the following equation:
s ¼ L=Rs:A (2)
where Rs is the surface resistance measured using a standard fourprobe method, and L and A are the length and cross-section of nanocomposite film, respectively, measured by calibres.
The conductivity data was fitted with the classical percolation power law [51]:
s ¼ s0ðf fcÞt (3)
where s is the electrical conductivity (S.m 1), s0 is the scaling
factor, f is the fraction of conductive fillers (%), fc is the critical content of filler called conductive percolation threshold, and “t” is the critical exponent.
The TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites have a percolation threshold of fc # 0.46 wt% Fe3O4@RGO-PIL, which is similar to other values reported for TPU/graphene nanocomposites in the literature [52e55]. Nevertheless, it is about three times higher than the extremely low value of fc ¼ 0.078 vol.% recently reported for water borne PU/RGO-nanocomposites by Yousefi et al. [56]. However, such ultra-low RGO content can only be reached under high electrical field and leads to significant anisotropy not looked for in this study. Fig. 3b also shows that the conductivity of nanocomposites sharply increases initially from s ¼ 1 10 10 to 6 10 5 S.m 1 when the weight fraction of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL increases from 0.5 to 3 wt%, to later reach a plateau of larger conductivity of s¼ 1.5 10 3 S.m 1 for Fe3O4@RGO-PIL concentrations up to 10 wt%. This conductivity improvement is expected to result from better inter-sheets carrier transport and additional tunnelling contribution compared to the percolation threshold range. The dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) of TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL was investigated as a function of nanofillers' content from 0 to 5 wt% by recording the evolution of the storage modulus G0 during a temperature sweep from 100 toþ80 C (Fig. 3c). The storage modulus of the composite was found to increase with the Fe3O4@RGO-PIL content in the TPU matrix as reported by Quan et al. [57]. This positive synergy is evidencing a good dispersion of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL within TPU suggesting an interface of good quality between platelets and macromolecules and an optimal use of the high specific surface of graphene, which results in good stress transfer
from graphene nanoplatelets to the polymer matrix. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was used to examine the effect of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL on TPU thermal stability in nanocomposites (Fig. 3d).
It appears that pristine TPU starts to degrade at a temperature of 350 C, whereas for the corresponding nanocomposites the weight loss starts at higher temperatures, indicating an improvement of thermal stability with Fe3O4@RGO-PIL content in the TPU matrix. This confirms also the positive effect of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL addition to increase both storage modulus and thermal stability of TPU based nanocomposites. In particular PIL may act as a compatibilizer between graphene sheets and TPU chains by physico-chemical interactions affording good compatibility and more uniform integration, as already noticed for aniline functionalized CNT dispersed in PUmatrix [58]. The previous conclusionmakes that for TPU-Fe3O4@RGO-PIL, the already well-known relationships between homogeneity of fillers' dispersion in the matrix, quality of stress transfer and derived mechanical properties, can be extended to the uniformity of heat distribution and heat transfers avoiding weak points that may initiate global degradation.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Piezo-resistive behaviour in static mode
sections.text:
Interestingly, Fig. 4 shows the evolution of piezo-resistive source signals of Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites for different Fe3O4@RGO-PIL contents, 1, 3 and 5 wt% under several static compression loads ranging from 1 to 200 N. For each experimental condition the points correspond to the average values on three
specimens, in order to provide a statistical significance to data. All specimens were found to exhibit a strong negative piezo-resistive coefficient (NPC) characterized by a decrease of one or more decades in resistance with increasing compressive loadings. In TPU/ Fe3O4@RGO-PILconductive nanocomposites, the circulation of free electrons is easy in graphene sheets and good in Fe3O4but more difficult in PIL and almost impossible in TPU. Thus, the weak points of conductivity are the junctions between good conducting materials throughwhich electronsmust make their waymore difficultly. Therefore, any application of pressure on the percolated conductive architecture will cause movements and relaxations of polymer chains, which in turn will affect the global conductivity of the PU/ Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposite.
The change in resistance with pressure can be explained by two phenomena that can occur within the conducting architecture: firstly, the formation/destruction of conductive connections(switching) and secondly, the modification of existing junctions' distance (tunnelling) [56e62]. Although the conducting network is composed of a variety of junctions in terms interparticular distance or gap (d), it is possible to classify them in two main categories: close contact junctions for d < 1 nm and tunnelling junctions for 1 < d < 10 nm [59,62e65]. When the pressure applied on such system is increasing, the average interparticular distance d is decreased leading to better connections between conducting nanofillers and hence lower relative resistance of the nanocomposite film. Thus, Fe3O4nanospheres homogeneously distributed on both faces of graphene sheets act as nanospacers able to increase the inter-particular gap, thus making the conducting architecture less dense and more sensitive to compression. In such configuration the pressure applied on the graphene house of card structure induces the formation of new conductive pathways [62,66e68], which explains the NPC effect observed in the TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites. Fig. 4 also reveals the best performances of TPU-1 wt% Fe3O4@RGO-PIL in terms of reproducibility and sensitivity to pressure due to its vicinity to the percolation threshold, leading to a larger reconnection ability upon pressure. It is the reason why this nanocomposite formulation was selected for further investigation of its piezoresistive behaviour. In order to more deeply understand the effect of nanocomposites' composition and structure on their conduction behaviour during compression, typical current-voltage (IeV) traces
have been plotted for the different nanocomposite films and summarized in Fig. 5. These results show that below an applied stress of 120 kPa, all IeV curves are linear, indicating an ohmic conduction. Ohmic conduction assumes that the active conductive pathways inside the TPU matrix are made of nanofillers in close contact. Increasing stress applied just increases conductivity (the slope of curves is 1/R) due to the decrease of interfillers' gap. However, above 120 kPa the IeV curves become nonlinear features for voltage larger than 1 V. This non-ohmic behaviour is due to the additional contribution of tunnelling conduction.
The highest the potential applied to the sensor, the more important the energy given to electrons to “jump” at junctions and the larger the gap they can cross. More generally these results show the sensing potential of TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites in terms of tunnelling effect that can be “activated” by stress and/or compression.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Piezo-resistive behaviour in cyclic mode
sections.text:
Therefore, the nanocomposite sensors' resistance variation has been monitored under cyclic loadings increasing from 60 to 240 kPa. Four cycles were performed for each loading condition to check the reproducibility of specimen. As shown in Fig. 6a, the sensor's responses Ar are perfectly synchronic with deformation and stress. The variation of resistance closely follows the deformation (and applied stress) which returns to its original value after unloading. It can also be observed that for small deformations (first four cycles) the signal is linear but then quickly exhibits non-linear features. This trend is even more clear in Fig. 6b that evidences two behaviours taking place roughly below and over 180 kPa. In this later case an asymptote is reached for about 200 kPa, which does not compromise the repeatability of the response as the traces of the three consecutive cycles of loading/unloading are almost perfectly superimposable. Only a very small deviation is observed between the first and the third loops, indicating that the process usedwas very effective to homogeneously disperse Fe3O4@RGO-PIL conductive nanofillers into the TPU matrix. The piezo-resistive macroscopic behaviour is resulting from structural modifications taking place at the micro and nano scales in the nanocomposite [69]. However, in the case of filled elastomer nanocomposites, molecular relaxations triggering resistance changes can be strongly dependent on the filler content, its shape factor (1D such as
from 0.5 to 2400 kPa.
nanotubes or 2D like nanofoils), the nature of the matrix and the type of solicitations. Knite et al. have found that both hysteresis and sensitivity of poly(isoprene)-carbon nanoparticles PI-CNP nanocomposites were depending on cross-linking degree [6,70] and amount of CNP in relation with the vicinity to the percolation threshold [71]. The hysteresis is of course more important in extension than in compression as the deformations are larger in the first case (especially if samples are thin); below the elastic limit which is often around ε ¼ 10e15% for elastomer based nanocomposites, the phenomenon can be reversible and can eventually be linked to heat exchanges due tomolecular friction, whereas over the linear range it must take its origin in either sliding and/or breakage in the conducting percolated network and/or in the polymer matrix (physically or chemically cross-linked) [72e74]. In this case a non-reversible behaviour is expected, characterized by a drift in initial resistance [75].
Interestingly TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites are very stable and exhibit neither hysteresis upon loading/unloading nor creep that would introduce non-reversibility drift in resistance. Even if samples' thickness is rather small (e ¼ 0.1 mm), it is likely that the functionalization of graphene had a stabilizing effect, as also observed in poly(vinyledene difluoride) PVDF matrix by Ramaprabhu et al. [54]. The same authors evidenced that this trend was less marked with functionalized carbon nanotubes, more sensitive to non-reversible behaviour. To go further in the understanding of the origin of the piezo-resistive behaviour depicted in Fig. 6b, it is necessary to distinguish three ranges of deformation. In the first one, up to ε ¼ 12%, DR/R0 decreases linearly with the applied stress due to the combined effects of the inter-nanofillers'
spacing decrease, and new connections' formation. In this linear domain, the piezo-resistive coefficient (also named gauge factor, G) can be graphically determined from the slope of the curve in Fig. 6b and calculated with Eq. (4):
G ¼ DR R0
DL L0
(4)
where Ar¼DR=R0 is the response amplitude or relative change in resistance, and ε ¼ DL=L0 is the deformation of the sensor.The value of G # 6.2 obtained for TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL films is rather high as far as pure compression is considered. In the second range of deformation, for 12 < ε < 25%, a strongly non-linear decrease of Ar is observed. In this state, the rate of creation of new connections is decreasing as the average inter-particular distance and free compressible volumes are becoming more and more tiny.
In the third range of deformation, over ε ¼ 25%, any further increase in stress will result in almost no reduction in resistance and consequently in a weak response tending to a plateau. The system has reached its limit of compressibility; no structural change can result in any modification of the electrons' circulation. Thus, the nanocomposite pressure sensor will exhibit optimal sensitivity and durability in the first range of deformation, which leads to responses proportional to the solicitations and of large amplitude. This interpretation of relationships between structures and properties has been schematized in Fig. 6c, where RGO platelets have a 3D house of cards structure inside the polymer matrix, Fe3O4 NP acting as nanospacers to control the separation of RGO
nanofoils and PIL molecules compatibilizing the nanofillers with poly(urethane) macromolecules. This original combination of nature and architecture of the different compounds of the nanocomposites is expected to explain the good sensitivity, reproducibility, and stability of piezo-resistive signals obtained in compression.
To better understand the contribution of each compound, the piezo-resistive responses of TPU-1 wt% Fe3O4@RGO-PIL,TPU/RGOPIL and TPU/RGO nanocomposites, exposed to four cycles of 180 kPa compressive stress, have been compared in Fig. 7. All samples were prepared separately, but in the same conditions and were chosen with similar initial resistances R0 to make sure that the differences
observed will not depend on this parameter. At first sight, Fig. 7a shows that of the amplitude of TPU/RGO responses are the weakest of the set at about Ar # 0.30 ( 30%) and additionally the signals are rather noisy. The relative scattering of points and the delay to transduce the stress into a variation of resistance, may come from a more important staking of RGO platelets in the TPU matrix that penalizes the capacity of the conducting network to create new junctions, thus limiting resistance changes.
Fig. 7b shows that the piezo-resistive response of TPU/RGO-PIL has a twice larger amplitude (Ar # e 0.60) than TPU/RGO and less noisy signals. Moreover, the curvature of the response is inversed, which means that the transduction of stress into resistance change is must quicker in the nanocomposite containing PIL. The beneficial effect of PIL is that its coating of RGO surface not only helps the platelets dispersion and stabilization in the TPU matrix but also prevents their self-aggregation. The response's shape also suggests that the conductive network has acquired a real tri-dimensionality that enhances the piezo-resistive effect. However, the signal still exhibits some unstableness at the transition between loading and unloading. Therefore, in Fig. 7c, it is clear that the addition of Fe3O4 in the nanocomposite's formulation is leading to responses of even larger sensitivity (Ar # e 0.90), shorter time to stability (t # 10 s), and exempt of noise.
These trends are even more evident in Fig. 8 which focusses on only one cycle, to evaluate the slopes of the nanocomposite sensors' responses in comparison with their mechanical solicitation in
compression. In particular, Fe3O4 nanoparticles appear to have a positive contribution by bringing tiny volumes able to slightly but regularly separate graphene foils, in order to prevent their close contact in the absence of stress. In turn this morphology tends to promote electron tunnelling and hopping in TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL making its piezo-resistive effect more effective than in other graphene based nanocomposites. In addition to sensitivity enhancement, Fe3O4 also contributes to signal's noise reduction (Fig. 8) which is worth to be noted as quite often increasing sensitivity will also increase the noise of signals.
The expression of the normalized slopes of the different curves collected in Table 1 allows to quantify the increase in responses' dynamics visible in Fig. 8 with the addition of respectively PIL and further on Fe3O4 NP in the TPU/RGO sensor's formulation. This shows that the different steps of formulation's optimization are improving both the stability of responses (decrease of noise and increase of regularity and symmetry between loading and unloading) and the dynamics of sensors, i.e., their normalized slope can remarkably be increased from 0.6 to 24.
To further investigate the limits of sensitivity of the device developed, i.e., the minimum stress detectable by a resistance change (threshold pressure, Ps), we have monitored the piezoresistive response of TPU/1 wt% Fe3O4@RGO-PIL films under cyclic compressive stress profile from 0 up to 18 kPa. The results presented in Fig. 9 show that the sensor has a linear response fitting very well the mechanical solicitation. It is striking to notice that it can monitor tiny variations of stress with good sensitivity, Ar ¼ 0.1 for only a 3 kPa increment. Particularly, the threshold pressure of Ps ¼ 0.5 kPa measured is, to our knowledge, the lowest value that a piezo-resistive carbon based polymer nanocomposites can sense.
To compare with previous works found in the literature, a threshold pressures for resistance change of Ps ¼ 7 MPa was obtained for poly(ethylene) filled with 7 vol.% of graphite nanosheet (PE-GN) [76], and a positive piezo-resistive coefficient (PPC) of Ar ¼ 1.36 for a pressure increasing from 0.3 to 0.7 MPa (average finger pressure range although this depends on individuals [77]) was obtained for poly(dimethyl siloxane) filled with graphene nanosheets (PDMS-GN) nanocomposites [59], their samples were rather thick, 2 mm, they studied only ten cycles and reported no value of GF. Moreover, Ps ¼ 5 and 2 MPa were reported for poly(imide)/single wall carbon nanotubes PI-SWCNT [64] and poly(ether ether ketone)/multi walls carbon nanotubes PEEK-MWCNT [78] nanocomposites respectively. A value of Ar ¼ 0.2 for a pressure of 2 MPa was reported for poly(vinyl ester) filled with 0.3 wt% of multiwall carbon nanotubes (PVE-MWCNT) [74] and J. Hwang et al. [62] have prepared poly(dimethyl siloxane)-poly(3hexylthiophene)-modified multiwall carbon nanotubes (PDMS/ P3HT-MWCNT) nanocomposite giving an Ar ¼ 1.2 for a pressure variationDP¼ 0.12MPa, they have obtained sensors with PPC effect and a minimum detectable stress Ps ¼ 25 kPa, without mentioning the associated G. Some other works can also be mentioned: Z. Bao et al. [79] found that PDMS-CNT skins could have a resolution of minimum detectable stress in compression of 50 kPa in a time scale of 125 ms and a capacitive gauge factor of GF ¼ 0.004 but the study concerns only 4 cycles and on long term study is shown, J. Bai et al.
[80] obtained a very high GF ¼ 103 and low detectable pressure of Ps ¼ 0.6 kPa with PDMS filled with CNT-Gr hybrids but in compression conditions that actually make the conductive network more sensitive to lateral extension leading to a positive piezoresistive coefficient (PPC) instead of a negative one (NPC) as in our case, due possibly to samples' important thickness (3 mm) compared to our samples of 100 mm and to a larger contribution of high aspect ratio nanofillers such as CNT. These authors have obtained reproducible piezo-resistive signals over 100 cycles. In a previous work, we had synthesized a poly(isoprene)-reduced graphene oxide PI-RGO giving Ar ¼ 0.4 for a pressure variation of DP ¼ 100 kPa [81].

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Piezo-resistive behaviour in fatigue
sections.text:
To demonstrate the durability and robustness of our sensors, we first submitted them to the same kind of cycles as previously but for a longer time, which can be considered as a short fatigue sequence. The pressure solicitation and piezo-resistive response are overlaid in Fig. 10 to evidences the good synchronicity between them and the high stability of the TPU/1 wt% Fe3O4@RGO-PIL sensor trace for a short fatigue duration at low frequency. More precisely Fig. 10a is a data extraction of the piezo-resistive response of the sensor between the 256th and the 300th cycle using the same kind of solicitation as in former experiments, i.e., a loading/unloading speed of 5 mmmin 1 at f¼ 0.008 Hz, under a maximum load amplitude of 16 kPa. In this sequence there is no apparent change in amplitude nor average response, and there is an almost perfect matching between the mechanical and electrical signals. Fig. 10b which shows a magnification of the same signals in a narrower window, between the 290th and the 295th cycle, evidences that the sensor is remaining robust and is still well following the stress applied. Additionally, there is no apparent dephasing between signals, whichmeans that at this frequency and loading speed, the response is almost instantaneous.
Moreover, to push ahead the investigation of the fatigue on the long term, the piezo-resistive behaviour of nanocomposite sensors has been studied under sinusoidal loading at a 188 times higher frequency, i.e., f ¼ 1.5 Hz for amplitudes of pressure below 25 kPa. The results are presented in Fig.11a and correspond to an extraction of data after the 100 000th cycle. Even after so many solicitations, the piezo-resistive signal is still keeping its shape and regularity. Nevertheless, on Fig. 11b a slight dephasing of about Dt ¼ 2 ms is appearing which corresponds to the delay between the applied stress and the piezo-resistive response resulting from the increase
of the frequency. Therefore, it can be concluded that the nanocomposite formulation optimized for pressure sensing, TPU/1 wt% Fe3O4@RGO-PIL, is also operational after multiple loading/unloading cycles.
This quick overview confirms the interesting piezo-resistive characteristic brought by the sensing hybrid nanomaterials developed in the present work, which combines robustness upon loading/unloading, ultra-high sensitivity and stability under extremely low pressure. These advantages hold great potential in various applications such as tactile sensors and wearable electronics (see the video, in Supporting Information).
Supplementary video related to this article can be found at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2016.07.018.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
It has been shown in this paper that it was possible to synthesize strongly piezo-resistive nanostructured TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL nanocomposites from the assembly of only 1 wt% of magnetitedecorated reduced graphene oxide mediated by poly(ionic liquid) and TPU matrix. It is believed that the high performances of this material, G ¼ 6.2, Ps ¼ 0.5 kPa, a linear response in a large range of pressures (10e200 kPa), low noise and loading/unloading reversibility, come from its original 3D conducting architecture. In this system poly(ionic liquid) effectively exfoliated and stabilize graphene nanofoils whereas Fe3O4 NP played an important roles in the preservation of RGO sheets reconnection potential acting as
nanospacers, thus enhancing the piezo-resistive effect of the nanocomposite, its reliability and decreasing its limit of detection. Moreover, the robustness of sensors was demonstrated during fatigues tests at f ¼ 1.5 Hz for amplitudes of pressure below 25 kPa over 100 000th cycles that led to only slight dephasing of 2 ms between the sinusoidal load and the piezo-resistive signal. Additionally, the thermoplastic poly(urethane) used fully satisfied the requirements associated to a good matrix in terms of processing, dispersion, protection. Finally, the sensing films of TPU/1 wt% Fe3O4@RGO-PIL have demonstrated that if synergistic interactions between compounds can be obtained, it is possible to develop a multifunctional nanomaterial, combining flexibility, resilience, piezo-resistive and magnetic properties, that should have a variety of applications in flexible and wearable electronics, such as tactile sensors, sensing skins and compressive strain sensors.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was supported by a grant of University of South Brittany (France). We are grateful to Herv e B ellegou and Kishor Kumar Sadasivuni for their contributions to this work.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary information
sections.text: Supplementary information related to this article can be found at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2016.07.018.

metadata.abstractText: A robust piezo-resistive nanocomposite flexible sensor has been developed using an innovative combination of materials, i.e., magnetite-decorated graphene/poly(ionic liquid) compatibilized poly(urethane) (TPU/Fe3O4@RGO-PIL). The transducer has been fabricated by spray layer by layer (sLbL) to structure an original three-dimensional architecture in which: reduced graphene oxide (RGO) platelets are used to build the conducting network, PIL stabilizes this percolated assembly, Fe3O4 NP act as nanospacers between platelets to prevent their stacking and facilitate their switching, and TPU matrix brings cohesion and flexibility to the whole assembly. This strategy results in highly sensitive TPU/Fe3O4@RGOPIL flexible nanocomposite sensors (high gauge factor in pure compression up to 6.2, exceptionally low threshold pressure 0.5 kPa, Negative Pressure Coefficient), yielding a linear response in a large range of pressures (10e200 kPa), with robust and reproducible piezo-resistive properties (weak hysteresis upon loading unloading cycling, stability of signals up to 100 000 cycles, with 2 ms dephasing). These performances are promising for a variety of applications in flexible and wearable electronics, such as tactile sensors, sensing skins and compressive strain sensors. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
